crispr_hmm package

Submodules

crispr_hmm.hmm_alignment module

class crispr_hmm.hmm_alignment.hmm_model(reference_sequence, delta=0.3, tau=0.3, epsilon=0.6, gamma=0.6, rho=0.03, pi=0.03, q=0.4, p=0.9)[source]

Bases: object

The class to perform sequence alignment with hidden Markov model.

Parameters:

  • reference_sequence (str) – a reference sequence.

  • delta (float, list) – the transition probability from match state to deletion state.

  • tau (float, list) – the transition probability from match state to insertion state.

  • epsilon (float, list) – the transition probability from deletion state to deletion state.

  • gamma (float) – the transition probability from insertion state to insertion state.

  • rho (float) – the transition probability from deletion state to insertion state.

  • pi (float) – the transition probability from insertion state to deletion state.

  • p (float) – the emission probability of match. The emission probability of mismatch is 1-p.

  • q (float) – the emission probability of insertion and deletion. q should be smaller than p

Baum_Welch_estimator(seqs, method='Constrained_MLE', param_to_estimate=['delta', 'tau', 'epsilon', 'gamma'], lower_bound=None, ncores=1, tol=0.001, MAX_iter=100, echo=True)[source]

Estimate parameters with the Baum-Welch algorithm.

Parameters:

  • seqs (list) – Required: A list of mutated sequences.

  • param_to_estimate (list) – A list of parameters to estimate. Options are: delta, tau, epsilon, gamma. The default are [“delta”,”tau”].

  • method (str) – The estimating method to use. Options are: MLE and MAP. The default is MLE.

  • lower_bound (dictionary) – The lower bound of parameters. The format is the same as upper bound. By default, the lower bound is set to 0.20 for all parameters.

  • tol (float) – stop the estimation if the percentage of likelihood increase is less than the input value of tol.

  • MAX_iter (int) – the maximum number of iterations to perform.

  • echo (boolean) – Print the likelihood at each iteration.

EM(seqs, ncores=1)[source]

Compute the updated parameters with the Baum-Welch’s expectation maximization procedure.

Parameters:

  • seqs (list) – Required: A list of mutated sequences.

  • method (str) – The estimating method to use. Options are: MLE and MAP. The default is MLE.

Returns:

The updated parameters in a dictionary and the likelihood of the model.

Return type:

tuple

backtrace(t, M, D, I, R)[source]

Get the best alignment by backtrace through the matrices computed by the function viterbi_matrices(t).

Parameters:

  • t (str) – A mutated sequence.

  • M – the match matrix computed by viterbi_matrices.

  • D – the deletion matrix computed by viterbi_matrices.

  • I – the insertion matrix computed by viterbi_matrices.

  • R – the back trace matrix computed by viterbi_matrices.

Returns:

The alignment outcome: (reference sequence, mutated sequence,

alignment log(probability).) :rtype: tuple

backward(t)[source]

Compute matrices with the backward algorithm.

Parameters:

t (str) – A mutated sequence.

Returns:

Three matrices computed by the backward algorithm: (match, deletion, insertion).

Return type:

tuple

calc_psi(state, AM, AD, AI, BM, BD, BI)[source]

Calculate psi using the forward-backward matrices.

Parameters:

state (str) – To compute the psi of which state. Options are: M (for match), D (for deletion), I (for insertion).

Returns:

A matrix of psi.

Return type:

numpy array

calc_xi(t, state1, state2, AM, AD, AI, BM, BD, BI)[source]

Calculate xi (the marginal transition probability from state1 -> state2) using the forward-backward matrices.

Parameters:

  • state1 (str) – The first state. Options are: M (for match), D (for deletion), I (for insertion).

  • state2 (str) – The second state. Options are: M (for match), D (for deletion), I (for insertion).

Returns:

A matrix of psi.

Return type:

numpy.ndarray

calculate_alignment_probability(aligned_ref, aligned_seq, use_log=False)[source]

Calculate the probabity of a alignment.

Parameters:

  • aligned_ref (str) – The reference sequence after alignment. e.g. A-T

  • aligned_seq (str) – A mutated sequence after alignment. e.g. AC-

  • use_log (boolean) – return log of probability.

Return float:

The probability of the alignment.

viterbi(t)[source]

Perform the Viterbi algorithm to generate the best alignment between the reference sequence and a mutated sequence t.

viterbi_matrices(t)[source]

Compute the matrices with the Viterbi’s dynamic programming algorithm.

Parameters:

t (str) – A mutated sequence.

Returns:

Four matrices computed by the Viterbi algorithm: (match, deletion, insertion, back trace matrix).

Return type:

tuple

  • t (str) – A mutated sequence.

Returns:

The best alignment between the model.reference_sequence and t.

crispr_hmm.util.calculate_psi_by_iteration(model, t, state, pos)[source]

Calculate the psi (marginal probability) of a particular state by summing over the the possible alignment through iteration.

Parameters:

  • model (object) – A hmm_model object.

  • t (str) – The second sequence.

  • state (str) – The hidden state of psi. Possibilities are: M, I and D.

  • pos (int) – The position of hidden state.

Returns:

The marginal probability of psi(state, pos).

Return type:

float

    .

  • t (str) – The second sequence.

  • t (str) – The second sequence.

crispr_hmm.util.get_xi_by_iteration(model, t, state1, pos1, state2, pos2)[source]

Calculate the xi (marginal probability) of a particular state transition (state1,pos1) -> (state2,pos2) by summing over the the possible alignment through iteration.

Parameters:

  • model (object) – A hmm_model object.

  • t (str) – The second sequence.

  • state1 (str) – The first hidden state. Possibilities are: M, I and D.

  • pos1 (int) – The position of the first hidden state.

  • state2 (str) – The second hidden state. Possibilities are: M, I and D.

  • pos2 (int) – The position of the second hidden state.

Returns:

The marginal transition probability from (state1, pos1) to

(state2, pos2). :rtype: float

crispr_hmm.util.linear_prior(parameter, MAX, MIN, MAX_POS, length)[source]

Generate linear prior for a transition probability of the following parameters: delta, tau, gamma, pi. Persumbly, the transition probability is highest at the CRISPR induced DSB site and decreases as it moves further.

Parameters:

  • parameter (str) – Which of the following parameter: delta, tau, gamma, pi.

  • MAX (float) – The maximum probability.

  • MIN (float) – The minimum probability.

  • MAX_POS (int) – The position of reference sequence where the transition

probability is the highest. e.g. 4bp upstream to the PAM.

Parameters:

length (int) – The length of the reference sequence.

Returns:

A list transition probability from the first position to the last position.

Return type:

list[float]

crispr_hmm.util.plot_params(model, params=['delta', 'tau', 'epsilon', 'gamma'], colors=['gray', 'gray', 'gray', 'gray'])[source]

Plot the transition probability of a model.

Parameters:

  • model (object) – A hmm_model object.

  • t (str) – The second sequence.

  • params (list) – A list of parameters to plot. Default: [“delta”,”tau”,”epsilon”,”gamma”].

  • colors (list) – A list of colors to use. Default: [“gray”,”gray”,”gray”,”gray”].

Returns:

Figures of transition probability.

Return type:

figure
